1.speaker: Gale
1.text: I'm certain it was merely prudence steering Jaheira's hand, and not any mistrust as to our heroic abilities.
1.context: NodeContext: Seeking to reassure - Jaheira implied they weren't worthy to succeed her as heroes

142.speaker: Gale
142.text: Fairly certain. Prudence was a contributing factor, at the very least.
142.context: NodeContext: Losing confidence but trying not to sound too defeatist

4.speaker: Gale
4.text: If that charlatan Lorroakan thinks he can best Dame Aylin, he's even more clueless than I believed.
4.context: NodeContext: Almost amused by the thought, a bit of schadenfreude at his peer's idiocy

276.speaker: Gale
276.text: We should inform her of his delusions. No doubt she'll have great fun dispelling them.
276.context: NodeContext: Almost amused by the thought, a bit of schadenfreude at his peer's idiocy

6.speaker: Gale
6.text: A devil and devil hunter, standing shoulder to shoulder against a common enemy. Rather poetic, I think.

13.speaker: Gale
13.text: A privilege to witness such a reunion. Shadowheart deserves to have her family restored, when Shar has taken so much from her already.

15.speaker: Gale
15.text: You possess great strength of will, to resist the lure of such powers as Cazador sought to wield.

224.speaker: Gale
224.text: An admirable choice, if not one that will make achieving our purpose any easier.
224.context: NodeContext: Not overly concerned by the choice, wouldn't have minded Astarion wielding the vampire lord's powers

17.speaker: Gale
17.text: I can't imagine how Astarion must be feeling. The terms of your own condemnation carved into your skin... A monster's actions. And monsters do not deserve such power as that ritual promised.
17.context: NodeContext: A blunt observation, but with a hint of sympathy

38.speaker: Gale
38.text: When the time comes, Astarion will have his revenge I'm sure. And it will be richly deserved. But not yet, so what can I do for you?

18.speaker: Gale
18.text: I think we taught that inquisitor a very valuable lesson. He won't be ambushing anyone else in a hurry. Or doing anything else, for that matter.

19.speaker: Gale
19.text: A pity Shadowheart chose to depart our company. I'd grown quite fond of that Sharran wit of hers.

26.speaker: Gale
26.text: We have our first victory, but we'll need more before this day is through. The momentum is with us - we must keep moving.

27.speaker: Gale
27.text: What life is left to you now, I wonder? A slow decline? A sudden, painful extinguishing? Bhaal does not forgive.
27.context: NodeContext: Pity mixed with curiosity -  the DU was cursed by their god to a slow decline. Gale may or may not like them, so should be fairly neutral tothe outcome

28.speaker: Gale
28.text: I shouldn't speculate on such matters. We'll find out in due course, I'm sure.

39.speaker: Gale
39.text: A githyanki joining our company. Not a collaboration I'd have anticipated, but a welcome one nonetheless.

41.speaker: Gale
41.text: Orin, masquerading as Minthara... That certainly explains her vociferous antipathy towards me.
41.context: NodeContext: Serious, but with a hint of relief. Referring to Minthara being taken by Orin

82.speaker: Gale
82.text: Who knows how long the real Minthara has been strapped to Orin's altar? We owe it to her to bring her back safely. She would do no less for you or I.

43.speaker: Gale
43.text: So much blood... I wonder, will I ever get the stink of it from my nostrils...
43.context: NodeContext: Annoyed, taking this as a personal slight

45.speaker: Gale
45.text: Revenge is a dish best served hot, it seems. At least when you're in charge of the menu.
45.context: NodeContext: Dark humour - your friend achieved her goal, but you know she'll not live long enough to celebrate

54.speaker: Gale
54.text: What will Voss have to show for himself when we catch up with him, I wonder?

277.speaker: Gale
277.text: His intelligence may yet prove the key to unlocking the artefact's secrets. We should ensure we follow up when we reach Baldur's Gate.

59.speaker: Gale
59.text: Beneath her forbidding countenance, I sense this cleric will prove quite the companion. A wise decision to let her join us.

60.speaker: Gale
60.text: Goblins aren't known for their cleanliness, but by Mystra's mantle, this place is rotten. The fewer breaths we take here, the better.

61.speaker: Gale
61.text: Thank Mystra for that. Can't say I was enamored with the thought of spending my final moments buried under a thousand tonnes of limestone.

73.speaker: Gale
73.text: Another joins our merry band. We'll need to keep our wits sharp around him, I think.

76.speaker: Gale
76.text: None should be forced to make such a choice. If Orpheus is willing to undergo ceremorphosis, then it is his will, and should be respected.
76.context: NodeContext: Impressed, finding this all very interesting

77.speaker: Gale
77.text: A grim sight to behold when you're as bone-weary as we are.
77.context: NodeContext: Referring to discovering Zevlor brutally murdered in camp by Orin. Slightly stunned by it

85.speaker: Gale
85.text: It is unsettling, to know we have such eyes as Orin's upon our party.
85.context: NodeContext: Referring to discovering Zevlor brutally murdered in camp by Orin. Slightly stunned by it. Reflective

318.speaker: Gale
318.text: Sorry - I didn't ask why you sought me out. Do you need anything of me?
318.context: NodeContext: Realising he's not asked why you came over, waking from his gloomy thoughts

80.speaker: Gale
80.text: Ceremorphosis is Karlach's only chance of survival. It must be her.
80.context: NodeContext: Impressed, finding this all very interesting

83.speaker: Gale
83.text: I've never seen such a concentration of shadow magic. We must forge on, but carefully. It will corrupt any who lack the power to control it.

292.speaker: Player
292.text: What's so different about shadow magic?

285.speaker: Gale
285.text: It is the very antithesis of all the Weave stands for, a magic of confusion and corruption, drawn forth only by those desperate or damned enough to accept its degradations.

235.speaker: Gale
235.text: Followers of Mystra - those who call on the true Weave - are expressly forbidden to indulge it.

391.speaker: Player
391.text: I thought Mystra was the god of all magic. Why forbid this?

388.speaker: Gale
388.text: Mystra's domain is the Weave, and the magic that courses through it.

107.speaker: Gale
107.text: These shadows were drawn from another source, created by another goddess: Shar.

11.speaker: Gale
11.text: Mystra cannot destroy it, even if she wishes to, but she can try to ensure her followers resist its temptations.

394.speaker: Gale
394.text: Now, I think it's time we moved on to lighter subjects, before we too are lost to the darkness. Was there anything else?

232.speaker: Gale
232.context: NodeContext: Slightly uncomfortable. Been asked if he could use a potentially evil kind of magic, if he wanted to...

47.speaker: Gale
47.text: Technically, of course I could dabble in such practices. I've yet to find a form of magic I'm not a born natural in wielding.
47.context: NodeContext: Slightly uncomfortable. Been asked if he could use a potentially evil kind of magic, if he wanted to... Mulling the thought over

144.speaker: Gale
144.text: As for whether I should wield it... that would rather depend on the circumstances. And how closely I felt Mystra was watching...
144.context: NodeContext: Slightly uncomfortable. Been asked if he could use a potentially evil kind of magic, if he wanted to... Mulling the thought over

293.speaker: Player
293.text: Didn't you use this magic to create the shadow lantern?

35.speaker: Gale
35.text: I did. But our situation warrants we explore every opportunity presented to us, however grim.

90.speaker: Player
90.text: These shadows are a blight. Only one already tainted with evil would seek to use such magic.

74.speaker: Gale
74.text: Magic has no inherent morality - it's effect is entirely down to the inclinations of the wielder.

163.speaker: Gale
163.text: Even Mystra herself abstains from passing judgement on those who use the Weave. Her job is to ensure magic exists, not to dictate the purposes to which it is applied.

176.speaker: Gale
176.text: There's no denying a certain perfume of decay hangs over such dark magic, but that isn't to say it can't be put to good use. Or at the very least, neutral use.

99.speaker: Player
99.text: Mystra's loathing of such magic is well founded. It taints everything it touches.

321.speaker: Player
321.text: Are you still bound by Mystra's doctrine?

66.speaker: Gale
66.text: I'd say I've learned to interpret it with a degree of flexibility.

108.speaker: Gale
108.text: Her doctrine is more than just a personal opinion - it forms the very essence of wizardry. I'm in no rush to discard it.

7.speaker: Player
7.text: I recognise Lady Shar's magic when I see it. You needn't point it out to me.

221.speaker: Gale
221.text: Of course. Sometimes I forget who I'm travelling with. It takes some getting used to, walking amongst peers again.

252.speaker: Gale
252.text: Whoever inflicted the shadows on this land was no ordinary spellcaster. And certainly had no fear of Mystra's punishment for doing so.

114.speaker: Player
114.text: As it should be. This magic is Lady Shar's to command, not Mystra's.

98.speaker: Gale
98.text: True enough. The gods can be loathe to tread on one another's toes, claws, wings and so forth. But they think little of controlling mortals.

254.speaker: Player
254.text: Shadow magic isn't Mystra's to claim, it might be said...

130.speaker: Player
130.text: Judging by the extent of the corruption, Mystra's powerless here.

135.speaker: Player
135.text: Could you use this shadow magic?

152.speaker: Player
152.text: Mystra's loathing of such magic is well founded. It taints everything it touches.

174.speaker: Player
174.text: I'm not unfamiliar with shadow magic, as it were. No need to explain it to me.

308.speaker: Player
308.text: What would it do to me?

139.speaker: Gale
139.text: A very hard thing to predict. We've already witnessed the myriad forms its corruption has inflicted on this land and its inhabitants.

390.speaker: Gale
390.text: I think a quick death is the best one could hope for.

51.speaker: Player
51.text: You're a wizard - shouldn't you be able to control it?

137.speaker: Gale
137.text: Not all wizards are made the same, nor do we wield the same powers.

304.speaker: Gale
304.text: This magic is the very antithesis of all the Weave stands for, a magic of confusion and corruption, drawn forth only by those desperate or damned enough to accept its degradations.

158.speaker: Player
158.text: You know me. I'm nothing if not exceedingly cautious...

239.speaker: Gale
239.text: Hmm. I suspect we define the word differently, but nonetheless - this is a place where it's best applied. This magic is dangerous.

10.speaker: Player
10.text: I recognise shadow magic when I see it. You needn't explain this to me.

84.speaker: Gale
84.text: The sooner we're back on solid ground, the better.
84.context: NodeContext: A blunt observation, but with a hint of sympathy

88.speaker: Gale
88.text: No sense dawdling. Karlach has precious little time left to her - we'd do better than to waste it.

89.speaker: Gale
89.text: Who knew Vlaakith and Mystra would have so much in common? Both set on flinging their followers towards destruction without so much as deigning to justify it.

14.speaker: Gale
14.text: Lae'zel's devotion is impressive, but if she's not careful it will be fatal. Gods consider mortals like us a cheap token to trade in for their desired outcomes, at least in my experience.

97.speaker: Gale
97.text: Walking freely out of a githyanki crèche... A miracle if ever I've seen one. And trust me, I've seen quite a few.
97.context: NodeContext: Being a bit of a know-it-all

100.speaker: Gale
100.text: To threaten the life of a child... truly, Orin will stop at nothing.

103.speaker: Gale
103.text: Our githyanki companion thinks little of killing those who deny her. An admirable quality, so long as her desires align with our own.

111.speaker: Gale
111.text: You made a good decision, refusing that devil's contract.
111.context: NodeContext: Annoyed, taking this as a personal slight

340.speaker: Gale
340.text: We'll speak more on this later, but suffice it to say for now - that crown is vital to our purpose here.

112.speaker: Gale
112.text: Please know - I've no desire to pry into anyone else's past, especially one that's left its scars.

226.speaker: Gale
226.text: I'll gladly talk to you about such matters when the time comes. But for now, let's speak of other things.

113.speaker: Gale
113.text: Nasty way to go, suffocating slowly under a tonne of rubble. Not a fate I'd personally relish.

115.speaker: Gale
115.text: What secrets does the aasimar promise to reveal, I wonder?
115.context: NodeContext: Curious, there's a mystery been hinted at

362.speaker: Gale
362.text: Whatever they are, Shadowheart will pay dearly for them. Shar will make sure of it.
362.context: NodeContext: Bleak observation - Gale knows enough about Shadowheart's goddess, Shar, to know she will suffer for her disobedience

117.speaker: Gale
117.text: A hero of legend, passing the figurative torch on to us.
117.context: NodeContext: Feeling important, enjoying the moment

149.speaker: Gale
149.text: We'd best not disappoint her - the thought of a scolding from Jaheira's ghost is not one I particularly relish.
149.context: NodeContext: Feeling important, enjoying the moment

118.speaker: Gale
118.text: Not entirely sure I'm a fan of being trapped at the bottom of the Chionthar. Better get ourselves out of here. Quickly.

122.speaker: Gale
122.text: I never thought this journey of ours would see us knocking on a devil's door. Can't say I'm relishing the experience, but needs must.

124.speaker: Gale
124.text: Lae'zel was a formidable addition to our party. Our odds without her are diminished.
124.context: NodeContext: Grim, this is a serious problem - referring to Lae'zel being abducted by Orin

323.speaker: Gale
323.text: We should consider Orin's terms carefully, however distasteful we may find them.

129.speaker: Gale
129.text: I think we've done rather a good thing here. A welcome change, to gift this land a sliver of hope amongst so much despair.

131.speaker: Gale
131.text: The situation demands more of you than any other, but you would not become an illithid in vain. Your transformation is the missing piece. It must be you.

133.speaker: Gale
133.text: Minthara's something of a closed book, but I suspect a heart of gold lurks beneath that stern countenance.
133.context: NodeContext: Annoyed, taking this as a personal slight

198.speaker: Gale
198.text: Once she gets to know me, I'm sure she'll open up. She's just waiting for someone ready to listen.

141.speaker: Gale
141.text: Careful where you tread here. A hag's magic is not to be trifled with.

145.speaker: Gale
145.text: I can't help feeling Wyll got off lightly. The wrath of the hells is second only the wrath of the heavens.
145.context: NodeContext: Speaking to Wyll: struggling to find the right words, trying to be positive. Speaking about Wyll: betraying a little more concern, but still thinks he did well with such a small punishment

307.speaker: Gale
307.text: Having a devil in our camp will certainly make things interesting. Never a dull day, is there?
307.context: NodeContext: Mildly amused/curious what this turn of events will bring

146.speaker: Gale
146.text: My apologies. I'm not quite myself just yet. I had the strangest dream last night. A visitor came to me, a vision of unparalleled beauty and power.

353.speaker: Gale
353.text: She told me she was watching over me, protecting me. And, that our tadpoles could prove beneficial, if we embrace what powers they have to offer.

373.speaker: Gale
373.text: An uncanny apparition. I'm not entirely sure what to make of it.

243.speaker: Player
243.text: You don't believe this was a real person talking to you then?

331.speaker: Gale
331.text: A real manifestation, perhaps. But not an individual of flesh and blood in the manner you or I would consider to be 'real.'

280.speaker: Gale
280.text: Whether she spoke the truth or not... Well, I think I require a little more evidence before taking a fantasy at her word.

191.speaker: Gale
191.text: Until then, best we speak of other matters. Was there something you wished to ask?

200.speaker: Player
200.text: I had the same dream. A similar visitor, with a similar message.

29.speaker: Gale
29.text: Very curious. In all my readings on the effects of illithid parasites, I've never come across any accounts of correlating dreams between infected parties.

168.speaker: Gale
168.text: Another unique quality of our predicament, perhaps. Are you inclined to take these visitors at their word?

261.speaker: Player
261.text: Of course not. It was a dream, nothing more.

49.speaker: Gale
49.text: Do not dismiss the truth of dreams out of hand. They can be portentous to quite alarming degrees.

165.speaker: Gale
165.text: Still, your caution in this instance is well-advised. Let's see whether our dream visitors come good on their promises, or if they too were no more than a passing illusion.

271.speaker: Player
271.text: I'm not sure. Such an apparition has its own motives, whatever it told us.

282.speaker: Gale
282.text: Nothing wrong with maintaining a healthy suspicion in such matters.

193.speaker: Gale
193.text: Still, it might be wiser to  keep an open mind on the matter. Our visitors' promises of aid might yet bear valuable fruit.

64.speaker: Player
64.text: I am. Something is delaying our transformation. Why not this 'dream visitor' of ours?

160.speaker: Gale
160.text: If so, we have far more to learn about the powers at play here. Our ignorance as to the exact nature and intent of our saviours is hardly cause for celebration.

233.speaker: Gale
233.text: I hope your confidence proves well-founded. God knows we could use all the help we can get.

259.speaker: Player
259.text: Best to ignore. Probably just something you ate.

367.speaker: Gale
367.text: Or perhaps, a certain parasite that's clamped its jaws into me. Regardless, you're right. Better to stay focused on the real world's problems, than the fantasy of an easy solution.

359.speaker: Gale
359.text: Speaking of which, I assume you came with some other subject on your mind?

147.speaker: Gale
147.text: I've not seen infernal flames like that in quite some time. Why go to Avernus, when you can bring Avernus to us?
147.context: NodeContext: Curious/pondering - a rhetorical question, no response from player

148.speaker: Gale
148.text: Not the resounding success we were hoping for. Still, the price of ambition is occasionally catastrophic failure. At least our skulls remain intact.

150.speaker: Gale
150.text: Whatever business Wyll has with Mizora, it will cost him dearly. Or worse still, it will cost us. I hope we can afford it.

151.speaker: Gale
151.text: If Gortash is to be believed, then even our camp isn't safe from Orin's influence. We might want to confirm the veracity of his claim. Or at least, clean up the mess.

154.speaker: Gale
154.text: It is no small thing to be a god's Chosen. Whatever life you once claimed to lead, it only follows from now on. Where Bhaal leads, you will be forced to go.
154.context: NodeContext: Really pissed off, not ready to talk about it. Learned the DU was an originator of the Absolute plot

196.speaker: Gale
196.text: You know this for yourself, of course. So was there some other matter you needed to discuss?

155.speaker: Gale
155.text: Orin was a monster, whatever her form. I suppose growing up somewhere like this would make a monster of anyone.

156.speaker: Gale
156.text: I've been dreaming of our enigmatic visitor again. She told me our purpose was to take on this 'Cult of the Absolute', to infiltrate its ranks and bring it down from the inside.

253.speaker: Gale
253.text: This 'source' she referred to and the 'Heart of the Absolute' might be one and the same.

356.speaker: Gale
356.text: I've no wish to cast any aspersions on our existing skill set, of course, but given the perilous direction in which our journey is headed, the tadpole's powers might be a welcome addition to our arsenal.

225.speaker: Player
225.text: Our tadpoles are part of the problem, not a solution. We shouldn't rely on them or their powers.

86.speaker: Gale
86.text: I admire the vigour with which you uphold your principles, but I would remind you that the evils of the Absolute are far greater than any moral compromise we might make by using our tadpoles' full potential.

16.speaker: Gale
16.text: Your confidence in our existing capabilities is quite rousing, though. Perhaps that spirited enthusiasm will be strength enough to subdue the Cult when the time comes.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: You're right. We must use every means at our disposal - even unsavoury ones.

180.speaker: Gale
180.text: As existential evils go, the Absolute certainly seems an adversary worth halting in its  tracks.

404.speaker: Gale
404.text: Any opportunities for us to indulge our tadpole's capabilities are hardly on the same scale. Trifles, when one considers the bigger picture.

20.speaker: Player
20.text: That remains to be seen. I still don't trust this dream visitor's intentions.

301.speaker: Gale
301.text: I suppose you're right - we still see only a part of the picture, however much our visitor claims to show the full vista of options at our disposal.

380.speaker: Gale
380.text: I can't deny my curiosity, but as you say - no harm in delaying it, for now at least.

183.speaker: Gale
183.text: She even offered me greater powers, the result of some manipulation of the tadpole's psionic abilities.

217.speaker: Gale
217.text: Given the magnitude of what we're up against, I see no harm in considering the benefit this offer might afford us. It could be the only way to reach this 'source' in one piece.

162.speaker: Gale
162.text: Dame Aylin has little to feel sorry about - Lorroakan would have inflicted a far worse fate on her, given the chance.
162.context: NodeContext: Not shaken at all by Lorroakan's death - no love lost between them

164.speaker: Gale
164.text: You look remarkably perky. Nothing like a good night's sleep to restore the senses.

167.speaker: Gale
167.text: I didn't expect to meet your kin patrolling these wilds so openly. Whatever they're seeking, they clearly feel no need to hide their efforts. Or their urgency.

169.speaker: Gale
169.text: Hmm. Go on then, state your business with me. From a safe distance, if it's all the same to you.

170.speaker: Gale
170.text: A brave choice, to kill the child of one god at the behest of another. Shadowheart's loyalty plumbs darker depths than I anticipated.
170.context: NodeContext: Curious, not sure what to make of Shadowheart after she performed a violent sacrifice

25.speaker: Gale
25.text: Let's hope the fruits of this cruel labour are to her advantage. And ours, of course.
25.context: NodeContext: Curious, not sure what to make of Shadowheart after she performed a violent sacrifice

171.speaker: Gale
171.text: Raphael revealed a cruel truth, but believe me when I say it is one you are more powerful for learning.

182.speaker: Gale
182.text: My opinion on such matters would be an uninformed one, I'm afraid. But is there anything within my expertise you wished to discuss?

172.speaker: Gale
172.text: The people of Faerûn will be well served with Wyll as their champion.

283.speaker: Gale
283.text: 'The Blade of Frontiers. A fitting title for one so steeled with purpose.
283.context: NodeContext: tongue in cheek regarding Wyll's heroic moniker

173.speaker: Gale
173.text: Not entirely sure that was a wise decision. Better the devil you know, I suppose. The one Wyll knows, at least.
173.context: NodeContext: 'Hmmm'. Wary but not leaping to any conclusions. Will wait and see how this pans out.

175.speaker: Gale
175.text: I know those githyanki weren't your kin per se, but I hope you know it gives me no pleasure that our actions condemned them to such a fate.

79.speaker: Player
79.text: My kin would never have been foolish enough to leave such a contraption intact. They deserved their fate.

378.speaker: Gale
378.text: A valid point. As survival strategies go, raising your young in a building rigged to self-destruct is a rather poor one. No doubt they'd have found that out for themselves eventually.

368.speaker: Player
368.text: This is our fault. We should've left that weapon alone.

257.speaker: Gale
257.text: A valid point. But I think it's safe to assume that were the boot on the other foot, they'd have few regrets. Ruthlessness cuts both ways. And crushes too.

386.speaker: Player
386.text: They deserved to die on the battlefield, serving Vlaakith, bloodied swords in hand. We denied them that honour.

31.speaker: Gale
31.text: Not all deaths are so laden with import, on this plane or any other. The best we can do is live well, and hope the death that comes for us is quick. And preferably painless. I think we gave them that, at least.

305.speaker: Gale
305.text: What's done is done, and what remains to be done allows no great periods of introspection on such matters. Unless there's something else to discuss, we should press on.

178.speaker: Gale
178.text: What Shadowheart did for her parents was a profound act of love. Her courage is... well, it's quite something to behold.
178.context: NodeContext: Almost in awe of Shadowheart's strength of will. A new/deepened respect for her.

179.speaker: Gale
179.text: There's no more radiant sight than that of someone who's learned to love themselves anew.
179.context: NodeContext: pleased for his friend, lofty air

327.speaker: Gale
327.text: Shadowed in name, but no longer in spirit. It suits her.

181.speaker: Gale
181.text: Druids will always follow nature's purpose over any mortal threat. Halsin goes where he is needed, as must we.
181.context: NodeContext: Understanding of Halsin's decision, not going to dwell on it

184.speaker: Gale
184.text: The bustle here takes some getting used to. A crackling fire and a tressym for company is usually more my speed.

264.speaker: Gale
264.text: Still, we must flow with the current we find ourselves in, however tumultuous it may be. If you've need of me, I'm glad to help.

185.speaker: Gale
185.text: Sounds like we're not the only ones tracking down this 'Minsc' fellow. Let's hope Nine-Fingers' bounty doesn't attract too much competition.

186.speaker: Gale
186.text: That githyanki officer didn't come here merely to fill our ears with idle gossip. Who resides within the artefact, I wonder?

75.speaker: Gale
75.text: Whatever Voss might have known about its occupant is lost to us now. Let's hope he and his alliance are aid we can do without.

187.speaker: Gale
187.text: Even the venerable Harpers are compromised by the Absolute's poison. A grim turn of events, but one we must take in our stride.

189.speaker: Gale
189.text: Do not be lured in by the Astral Plane's beauty. It is a lethal expanse, one we should be careful in attempting to cross.

190.speaker: Gale
190.text: As expected, Lorroakan falls short of any true academic standard. To believe Dame Aylin dead, based on a single subjective account?

244.speaker: Gale
244.text: It's just... shoddy scholarship. May she correct him with all the contempt of a thousand tenured professors.

194.speaker: Gale
194.text: Your new lease on life suits you rather well. What do you and your newborn vitality require of me?
194.context: NodeContext: Really pissed off, not ready to talk about it. Learned the DU was an originator of the Absolute plot

195.speaker: Gale
195.text: I hope Shadowheart's parents are a welcome balm for her wounds. There will be pain in defying such a malicious goddess, but perhaps no more than in obeying her.

197.speaker: Gale
197.text: Well that's my chances of a beauty sleep thoroughly ruined for the evening...

201.speaker: Gale
201.text: I imagine Wyll thought he'd have longer to enjoy the perks of his powers.
201.context: NodeContext: A blunt observation, but with a hint of sympathy

36.speaker: Gale
36.text: Such pacts always collect their dues in the end. His suffering has only just begun.
36.context: NodeContext: A blunt observation, but with a hint of sympathy

205.speaker: Gale
205.text: Orin toys with us where she could destroy us. Whatever her motivations, I hope she reveals them quickly.

206.speaker: Gale
206.text: What's done is done. No sense delaying further.
206.context: NodeContext: Focused - may or may not be annoyed at your decision, so should work for both

210.speaker: Gale
210.text: Come on then, don't leave me in suspense. How are you feeling? No errant tentacles? No sudden cravings for a more cerebral diet?

207.speaker: Player
207.text: I'm feeling great. Consuming these tadpoles could give us quite the advantage.

346.speaker: Gale
346.text: Wonderful. Advantages are a more precious commodity than I'd have hoped, given the nature of our predicament.

284.speaker: Gale
284.text: I commend you on your willingness to take such a risk. Now, let's hope your new, illithid-fuelled prowess tip the balance suitably  in our favour.

3.speaker: Player
3.text: Now you mention it, I do feel a sudden, unrelenting urge to crack open your... never mind.

231.speaker: Gale
231.text: Replete with ribaldry, as always. Well, you could provide no better proof that you are not, in fact, about to turn into a mind flayer.

241.speaker: Gale
241.text: Famously humourless, illithids. The tyrannical enslavement of all other living creatures hardly lends itself to levity. Should your wit begin to suffer, only then must we worry.

105.speaker: Player
105.text: No signs of ceremorphosis taking effect, if that's your concern.

104.speaker: Gale
104.text: I was rather more curious to know what benefits the tadpole might have bestowed, but no doubt the benefits of your change in diet will become apparent soon enough.

21.speaker: Gale
21.text: Was there another matter you wished to discuss?

213.speaker: Gale
213.text: Do you feel that? The Hells themselves tremble to face such a scourge as Wyll threatens to be.

123.speaker: Gale
123.text: 'The Blade of Avernus.' Forged by a cambion, whetted on a dragon's hide. Those devils won't know what's coming for them.

214.speaker: Gale
214.text: Tyranny offers only two fates for the tyrant - infamy, or ignomy. I'm glad we were able to offer Gortash the latter.

215.speaker: Gale
215.text: Fear not - I shall do nothing to embarass you amongst your peers. Where you lead, I follow with good humour, and the hope we might yet leave with both dignity and spleens unpunctured.

218.speaker: Gale
218.text: Is it me, or is the ground here particularly sticky? Almost as if...

406.speaker: Gale
406.text: Some thoughts are best left unfinished. Now, please tell me there's some other subject you wish to occupy my mind with?

219.speaker: Gale
219.text: Glad to see I'm not the only one on the wrong side of an omnipotent authority figure.

69.speaker: Gale
69.text: Lae'zel did well to break free of Vlaakith's manipulations. Though I doubt Vlaakith will let such insubordination go unpunished.

220.speaker: Gale
220.text: Not sure now is the time for chatter. There's a raging inferno surrounding us.
220.context: NodeContext: Coughing slightly - in the vicinity of a burning building, though not necessarily inside it

229.speaker: Gale
229.text: No amount of contracts will save Raphael from the fate we forced upon him. A devil well-slain, if I say so myself.
229.context: NodeContext: Annoyed, taking this as a personal slight

230.speaker: Gale
230.text: This Orphic Hammer sounds like quite the artefact. One I'll have no desire to consume, if that's your concern.
230.context: NodeContext: Annoyed, taking this as a personal slight

236.speaker: Gale
236.text: Whatever ancient purpose is imbued in these halls, it may not welcome our presence here. We should be wary of whatever lurks beneath the dust.

237.speaker: Gale
237.text: I've never had cause to visit a druid's grove before. Magic weighs heavier here, seeking solace in root and soil. Grounding, one might say.

238.speaker: Gale
238.text: Glad to see we all made it through the night intact. A promising sign that we may be able to curb those urges of yours.

24.speaker: Gale
24.text: Now as the saying goes, 'What's left undone should be left unspoken.' Is there some lighter subject you wish to discuss?

242.speaker: Gale
242.text: Whatever that thing was you turned into, I'd rather not see it again. By the gods...

246.speaker: Gale
246.text: The living may not be prevented from crossing a vampire's threshold, but that doesn't make us any more welcome. Tread carefully.

247.speaker: Gale
247.text: I feel the Weave growing more distant by the moment. We walk Shar's path now - best we don't spend too long in her shadow.

96.speaker: Gale
96.text: Wyll's father owes him gratitude. I hope for his sake Ravengaard is gracious enough to offer it, given how much it cost.

255.speaker: Gale
255.text: I know well the pain of seeing your life's hourglass running empty, grasping at any means of slowing the grains as they slip inexorably through your fingers.
255.context: NodeContext: Sincere, a note of pity - Gale once thought he was fated to die because of th orb, so her truly understands what she's going through

22.speaker: Gale
22.text: Karlach's fate may be ordained, but her actions are not. She will make each breath count - we can be sure of that.
22.context: NodeContext: Finding solace in the thought

256.speaker: Gale
256.text: Your siblings could use a dose of your cynicism. Anyone cruel enough to pursue such a means to power has no intention of sharing it.

227.speaker: Gale
227.text: But you don't need me to tell you this. You're here about something else, I'll wager?

258.speaker: Gale
258.text: So, a vampire lord walks among us. A powerful ally to have at our side, and a powerful enemy should our intentions diverge.
258.context: NodeContext: Impressed, finding this all very interesting

128.speaker: Gale
128.text: Things get more interesting by the moment.

262.speaker: Gale
262.text: A new kind of being walks among us. One with teeth.

37.speaker: Gale
37.context: NodeContext: Hint of darkness to this - it means your companion sacrificed thousand to gain power

263.speaker: Gale
263.text: The Astral Plane. Mortals such as we are not meant for this place. We must tread carefully.

267.speaker: Gale
267.text: Time for us to take a rather literal 'leap of faith'.

268.speaker: Gale
268.text: Poor Shadowheart. The gods are nothing if not vindictive in their vengeance.
268.context: NodeContext: Sympathetic - Gale also feels the gods have punished him

270.speaker: Gale
270.text: Shar's domain is a far cry from Mystra's. The Weave's light is truly extinguished by such darkness.

275.speaker: Gale
275.text: The Gur are certainly efficient. Astarion's fate will not be an easy one. Nor painless.

278.speaker: Gale
278.text: What a thrill, to wander the corridors of the forge of tyranny itself. Better keep our thoughts to ourselves - who knows what might be listening to us here?

279.speaker: Gale
279.text: An ally fresh from the Hells themselves. Our company grows stranger by the minute - and all the better for it.

287.speaker: Gale
287.text: That's one scourge eliminated. A vampire with that much power would be a death sentence for this city. A pity Astarion didn't understand that. Or rather, didn't care.

290.speaker: Gale
290.text: Of all the places I expected we'd find this Minsc, crawling from the broken jaws of a mimic wasn't high on my list. What's life without a few surprises, eh?

295.speaker: Gale
295.text: We cannot afford to lose focus now. Not when the brain is so close. We press on.
295.context: NodeContext: Urgent, decisive - this isn't the time for chit chat

300.speaker: Gale
300.text: Lae'zel had the makings of a formidable ally, if one prone to acts of impulsive violence.

281.speaker: Gale
281.text: Still, such conflicts will not serve our party well in resolving this little parasite problem of ours. Best we cast from the same spell book from now on.

302.speaker: Gale
302.text: At least Shadowheart is armed with the truth now. May its keen edge draw forth whatever vengeance she desires.

303.speaker: Gale
303.text: Whatever these dark powers of yours may be, they serve no purpose if you cannot control them. Or yourself. What a terrible waste.
303.context: NodeContext: Annoyed at the player - they've done something terrible, and dangerous

306.speaker: Gale
306.text: A fascinating structure. Made of living flesh, or merely a simulacrum?

78.speaker: Gale
78.text: A question for another time - for now, we'd best focus on finding a way out.
78.context: NodeContext: Remembering they might be in danger, re-focusing on the matter at hand

309.speaker: Gale
309.text: Let's hope Shadowheart's actions do not return to haunt her. I know they would haunt me.
309.context: NodeContext: Grim/shocked - can't quite believe Shadoheart stooped to murdering her own parents.

312.speaker: Gale
312.text: Halsin does not deserve to die on such a craven's altar.
312.context: NodeContext: Grim, this is a serious problem - referring to Halsin being abducted by Orin

315.speaker: Gale
315.text: A natural impulse to try and shield one's loved ones from danger, especially when you feel a moral compunction to run head-first towards it.

289.speaker: Gale
289.text: I suspect any child of Jaheira's will share her self-destructive sense of justice, but at least her words give them pause for thought.

316.speaker: Gale
316.text: All this time, we were protected by a mind flayer... that is a turn up for the books.
316.context: NodeContext: Not sure what to make of this new information

317.speaker: Gale
317.text: A shame it's so dank and decayed down here - I suspect there's a wealth of history to be uncovered, if any could hold their breath long enough to find it.

320.speaker: Gale
320.text: At last, we find a beacon of light amongst the darkness. And not a moment too soon - I'm quite ready for some respite.

324.speaker: Gale
324.text: Don't worry, I've no interest in prizing that artefact from your grip. Your secrets are yours to keep.
324.context: NodeContext: A blunt observation, but with a hint of sympathy

325.speaker: Gale
325.text: This is the seat of the Absolute's power. Whatever the 'Heart' is, it's connected to this place somehow. We must find out.

328.speaker: Gale
328.text: What joy, to have found the nadir of common decency. Let's conclude our business here quickly, and never speak of it again.

329.speaker: Gale
329.text: Hunting one devil, allying yourself with another. Our journey gets more curious by the second.

332.speaker: Gale
332.text: Quite the rug pull, eh? A mind flayer manipulating us this whole time.

72.speaker: Gale
72.text: Such creatures are not to be trusted, as a general rule, though this one does appear to have had a significant hand in our survival up to this point.

339.speaker: Gale
339.text: At best, an ally whose motivations remain shrouded in deceit. We should be wary of what such an alliance may cost us.

334.speaker: Gale
334.text: So, this is the seat of the Absolute's power? Every bit as vile as the cultists who flock here, by the looks of it.

335.speaker: Gale
335.text: Another day, another god trying to make us her playthings. We'll have the whole pantheon interfering with us if we're not careful.

337.speaker: Gale
337.text: At last, we stand on the cusp of victory. A narrower precipice than I hoped, but it's our destiny to traverse it nonetheless.

32.speaker: Gale
32.text: The brain will succumb, and these halls will echo with our deeds for generations. Greatness awaits.
32.context: NodeContext: Gale could be veering good or evil here, so Determined, focused. 'greatness' could take different forms, some selefish, some altruistic.

338.speaker: Gale
338.text: If there's heroism to be found in politics, I'm sure Wyll will find it. Somewhere...
338.context: NodeContext: Not that impressed by Wyll's decision, doesn't think politics is a particularly noble thing to aspire to

341.speaker: Gale
341.text: You should try to get some rest. Hard to save the world if you're stifling yawns.

342.speaker: Gale
342.text: I can't believe you signed that contract. We'll discuss this. Later.
342.context: NodeContext: Annoyed, taking this as a personal slight

348.speaker: Gale
348.text: I've known a few warlocks in my time. Talented, of course, though sometimes too eager to listen to the devils on their shoulders. Comes with the territory, unfortunately.

349.speaker: Gale
349.text: Time and again, Wyll's plight reinforces my decision not to pursue the path of a warlock.
349.context: NodeContext: Grim, a hint of pity

55.speaker: Gale
55.text: It's one thing to make such a sacrifice in the pursuit of such a pact, but to do so in order to escape one. Truly, it leaves you with nothing.
55.context: NodeContext: Grim, a hint of pity

350.speaker: Gale
350.text: Nothing like the stench of human effluence to make you regret any and all prior life decisions.

351.speaker: Gale
351.text: The tadpoles, the Absolute... it was because of you?  I think you've said and done more than enough. Leave me be.
351.context: NodeContext: Really pissed off, not ready to talk about it. Learned the DU was an originator of the Absolute plot

352.speaker: Gale
352.text: Fascinating as our surroundings are, we must press on. If our runaway general is down here, the Heart of the Absolute will be too.

354.speaker: Gale
354.text: We must reach Ketheric. He will lead us to the Heart of the Absolute.

357.speaker: Gale
357.text: Hardly the noblest conflict we've encountered, but criminals will have their squabbles, even in the looming shadow of utter annihilation.

358.speaker: Gale
358.text: Quite something, to have devotees of the Shar herself sworn to our cause.
358.context: NodeContext: Curious at this turn of events, should sound neutral as Gale isn't necessarily a fan of Shar

297.speaker: Gale
297.text: A pity Shadowheart was the price of it, but the 'Lady of Loss' will take her dues. Our loss is our gain, so to speak.
297.context: NodeContext: Grim, knows Shadowheart has a miserable life head. Last bit a play on 'their loss is our gain', as the player lost Shadowheart to gain the Shar temple's support

360.speaker: Gale
360.text: Jaheira made her choice, however unwise it may be to divide our efforts at this juncture. A shame, but we'll forge ahead without her.

361.speaker: Gale
361.text: You did a good thing back there. I won't dwell on the matter - I know that's not a sentiment you're accustomed to revelling in, but rest assured - your actions have spoken for themselves.
361.context: NodeContext: A blunt observation, but with a hint of sympathy

365.speaker: Gale
365.text: A savvy move, recruiting Halsin to our cause.
365.context: NodeContext: Annoyed, taking this as a personal slight

192.speaker: Gale
192.text: While I'm adept at most forms of Weave manipulation, druidic magic is not my area of expertise. He will make for a most useful option to have in reserve.

369.speaker: Gale
369.text: The hammer we claimed is of incredible arcane craftsmanship. No wonder it was so fiercely protected. In the wrong hands, who knows what it might shatter...
369.context: NodeContext: Annoyed, taking this as a personal slight

370.speaker: Gale
370.text: Not the kind of excitement I usually enjoy being woken up for. Still, better than not waking up at all. Or waking up as something else entirely.

372.speaker: Gale
372.text: A disturbed and disturbing night for all of us, but worth it. With due diligence, your impulses will soon be mastered. Or at least, prevented from causing further harm.
372.context: NodeContext: Shaken, but determined - the DU's impulse was to kill him the night before. Likely a romance partner/close friend of the DU, so seeking to reassure.

374.speaker: Gale
374.text: Revenge is a dish best served hot, it seems. At least when Karlach is in charge of the menu.
374.context: NodeContext: Dark humour - your friend achieved her goal, but you know she'll not live long enough to celebrate

333.speaker: Gale
333.text: She deserves more time to enjoy her victory. Still, there's solace to be found in surrendering one's mortality in a blaze of glory. Or so I hear.
333.context: NodeContext: Saddened, but trying to find a positive. Continuing the dark humour in alluding to the orb, and the fact he may yet go out in his own blaze of glory

375.speaker: Gale
375.text: The underdark has a certain menacing beauty to it. Though I'd be happier admiring it from a safe distance.

383.speaker: Gale
383.text: Minsc seems quite the, er, enthusiastic ally. We'd all do well to remain on his good side. And out of range of his fists.

384.speaker: Gale
384.text: Civilisation beckons at last. It's no Waterdeep, but Baldur's Gate is a respectable runner-up. Or at least a close third.

385.speaker: Gale
385.text: I've not felt the presence of the Shadow Weave like this since we left behind that cursed darkness. We must be on our guard.

389.speaker: Gale
389.text: Bested by simple vampire spawn, our companion snatched like a rattle from a babe.
389.context: NodeContext: Annoyed, taking this as a personal slight

344.speaker: Gale
344.text: Astarion's fate depends on us. Given our resounding failure to protect him in the first place, I'm not sure I fancy his chances.
344.context: NodeContext: Annoyed, taking this as a personal slight

392.speaker: Gale
392.text: Do you feel as flattered as I do? Invited to dine with a devil...

121.speaker: Player
121.text: Flattered? If that thing comes courting again I'll send it whimpering back to the hells.

286.speaker: Gale
286.text: Come now. Of all people I'd think you'd see through his bluster.

102.speaker: Gale
102.text: All that talk of desperation? It merely illustrates his own.

364.speaker: Gale
364.text: I think he wants something from us. Badly. And in that knowledge lies our opportunity.

211.speaker: Gale
211.text: Conjecture, yes - that much I concede.

199.speaker: Gale
199.text: But let me play the devil's advocate: the man is too eager. Do not dismiss his offer out of hand.

228.speaker: Gale
228.text: If there's one quality all the denizens of the Hells embody, it's ambition. A quality they share with many humans, come to think of it...

251.speaker: Player
251.text: What do you think Raphael's 'ambition' could be?

396.speaker: Gale
396.text: Haven't the foggiest. But based on the evidence before us, we can make certain deductions as to why he sought out our merry band.

299.speaker: Player
299.text: And how do you propose we beat a devil at his own game?

57.speaker: Gale
57.text: By figuring out his true intentions.

132.speaker: Gale
132.text: Fine - but my reasoning is this:

56.speaker: Gale
56.text: Admittedly, it's an area in which I have a modicum of expertise. And based on the evidence before us, it's hard to imagine any other motivation.

202.speaker: Gale
202.text: Fact one: there's something very strange and very powerful about our tadpoles.

216.speaker: Gale
216.text: Fact two: a devil offers to take it away.

377.speaker: Gale
377.text: Devils aren't known to aid mortals out of simple kindness. Whatever Raphael wants, we must be the key to getting it. Along with our tadpoles...

398.speaker: Gale
398.text: So I say for now - we wait. If I'm right, Raphael will seek us out again. And when he does, there's a mighty bargain to be made.

223.speaker: Gale
223.text: Remember his Cormyrian rhyme? 'Down came the claw'. Perhaps we should start growing our nails.

234.speaker: Player
234.text: But what is it that this devil wants so very badly?

53.speaker: Gale
53.text: Our souls. But I suspect that's but his opening offer.

296.speaker: Gale
296.text: Let me play the devil's advocate: the man is too eager. Do not dismiss his offer out of hand.

395.speaker: Player
395.text: I'll remind you that when dealing with a devil, you always draw the short straw.

95.speaker: Player
95.text: He only wants what all devils want: our souls.

161.speaker: Gale
161.text: There's no such thing as an absolute certainty.

0.speaker: Player
0.text: You have a strange definition of flattery.

70.speaker: Gale
70.text: Believe me, that was a devil's equivalent of serenades and roses.

106.speaker: Gale
106.text: Don't let his bluster fool you. All that talk of desperation? It merely illustrates his own.

40.speaker: Player
40.text: Dining with a devil left a bad taste in my mouth.

159.speaker: Gale
159.text: Yes... They offer you an apple, but they're the worm that lurks within.

274.speaker: Gale
274.text: Still - don't let his bluster fool you. All that talk of desperation? It merely illustrates his own.

366.speaker: Gale
366.text: I've never met a devil, but of course I've read a great deal about them.
366.context: NodeContext: Wants to impress upon you that his opinion is to be trusted

355.speaker: Gale
355.text: Even feigning a mortal form it was easy to detect the whiff of sulphur about him, to spot the flicker of hellfire in his eyes.

343.speaker: Player
343.text: Devils rarely approach mortals without some nefarious intent. We'd be wise to avoid him.

393.speaker: Gale
393.text: After all he'd been through... Zevlor did not deserve such a death.
393.context: NodeContext: Referring to discovering Zevlor brutally murdered in camp by Orin. Slightly stunned by it

397.speaker: Gale
397.text: Thank goodness that's all dealt with. The odds are stacked high enough against us already. No need to turn on each other.

400.speaker: Gale
400.text: Even being in the presence of that amulet makes my skin crawl. It's like feeling the eyes of Bhaal himself settling upon us.
400.context: NodeContext: With a shudder - just got a gross murderer amulet

402.speaker: Gale
402.text: I'll say one thing for our troupe - we're not short on drama. I'm glad Shadowheart and Lae'zel settled their differences peacefully. Eventually.

407.speaker: Gale
407.text: I hope your business with me isn't so contentious. I much prefer to settle matters with debate, not daggers.
407.context: NodeContext: A blunt observation, but with a hint of sympathy

409.speaker: Gale
409.text: A crying shame, to see such a curious piece of githyanki engineering reduced to junk parts. Still, at least it wasn't you who ended up on the scrap heap.

382.speaker: Gale
382.text: Yours was an escape narrow enough to defy even the tiniest of measuring sticks. Best to apply a touch more caution when agreeing to ambiguous medical procedures in future.

410.speaker: Gale
410.text: We have our orders, from your queen herself, no less. Now might be the time to consider obeying them.
